whereiation 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Summarize fields

analyze_data.Rd

Pivots data and summarizes factor frequencies by field and generates stats used for plotting

analyze_data(
  df,
  ...,
  avg_type = c("mean", "median"),
  return = c("data", "list")
)

Arguments

df

dataframe to evaluate
...

Arguments passed on to refactor_columns

dep_var

dependent variable to use (column name)

n_cat

for categorical variables, the max number of unique values to keep. This field feeds the forcats::fct_lump(n = ) argument.

n_quantile

for numeric/date fields, the number of quantiles used to split the data into a factor. Fields that have less than this amount will not be changed.

n_digits

for numeric fields, the number of digits to keep in the breaks ex: [1.2345 to 2.3456] will be [1.23 to 2.34] if n_digits = 2

ignore_cols

columns to ignore from analysis. Good candidates are fields that have have no duplicate values (primary keys) or fields with a large proportion of null values
avg_type

mean or median
return

option to return a dataframe when TRUE and a list when FALSE. The list option includes the original min/max of the data and the grand average.

See also

Other manipulation functions: generate_estimate_details(), refactor_columns()

Examples

analyze_data(iris, dep_var = "Sepal.Length")
#> Joining, by = "field"
#> # A tibble: 26 x 10
#>    field value factor_avg     n field_r_sq field_r_sq_adj field_p_value
#>    <fct> <chr>      <dbl> <int>      <dbl>          <dbl>         <dbl>
#>  1 Sepa~ 02 [~       5.31     7      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  2 Sepa~ 03 [~       5.89    22      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  3 Sepa~ 04 [~       6.22    24      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  4 Sepa~ 05 [~       6.02    37      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  5 Sepa~ 06 [~       5.69    31      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  6 Sepa~ 07 [~       5.26    10      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  7 Sepa~ 08 [~       5.75    11      0.110         0.0524      5.44e- 2
#>  8 Peta~ 01 [~       4.98    37      0.827         0.817       7.18e-50
#>  9 Peta~ 02 [~       5.07    13      0.827         0.817       7.18e-50
#> 10 Peta~ 05 [~       5.49     8      0.827         0.817       7.18e-50
#> # ... with 16 more rows, and 3 more variables: rescale_factor_avg <dbl>,
#> #   grand_avg <dbl>, field_wt <dbl>
analyze_data(iris, dep_var = "Sepal.Length", return = "list")
#> Joining, by = "field"
